text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with sriracha that's right we are
making our own homemade sriracha hot
sauce also known as rooster sauce also
known as hot another word for rooster
sauce and not only is making your own
hot sauce at home possible it's like
really fun so let me show you how to do
this and of course it's going to start
with hot red peppers I'm using two
varieties a red jalapeno also known as a
Fresno chili and I'm also going to use
some red serrano chiles which are much
hotter are you going to want to make
sure those are rinsed and drained very
thoroughly and then as far as prep go
all we're going to do is cut off the
stem end and then we're just going to
cut each pepper in four or five pieces
this is all going to get blended so the
size and shape really doesn't matter
same thing to the Serrano's and some
people do remove the seeds before they
chop these up alright because those
membranes around the seeds are where
most of the heat resides so some people
do remove that although I've always
considered those people kind of unclear
on the concept of a hot sauce so we're
going to use these as is alright so once
our peppers are prepped we're going to
go ahead and dump those into a blender
at which point we're gonna add the rest
of the ingredients which includes some
garlic we're also going to put in some
brown sugar some people use honey I use
brown sugar some salt and a little
splash of water just to help this blend
up and we're going to go ahead and puree
that until it's very smooth and you know
the drill
pulse on and off to start and then once
it gets going go ahead and turn it on
high speed until you have that
beautifully pureed alright so that looks
perfect at that point we're going to
transfer this into some kind of glass
jar or container or other nonreactive
material so I'm going to use this old
beer I mean milk pitcher and because the
next step is actually going to be the
fermentation we're going to call this a
pepper mash okay so we're going to
transfer our pepper mash into an
appropriate container we're going to put
some plastic wrap over it doesn't have
to be airtight we just want to keep the
critters out and then we're going to
place that in a cool dark location for
three days probably could possibly take
a day or two longer but we'll get into
that but like I said we're going to let
that ferment for three days and at least
once a day you can do twice if you want
but at least once a day you're going to
take it out and you're going to give it
a stir and do not be surprised if during
these daily stirrings you notice
tiny bubbles that would be the tell-tale
signs of fermentation all right so you
could see all those little bubbles
starting I believe this was after like a
day and a half for me and one quick tip
after you're done stirring I'd like to
scrape down the sides and I really don't
think that's that big of a deal but it
looks neater and after the daily
stirring and after you've cleaned the
sides go ahead and rewrap it put it back
in that cool dark place may I suggest
your garage or a basement this
definitely does have a distinct aroma as
if things were fermenting which they are
so if you have a spot outside the house
not a bad idea all right and then after
three days this is what mine look like
and again after three days if yours
doesn't seem like it's fermenting and
doesn't have all the bubbles mine does
let it go another day it's fine and by
the way this is all perfectly safe any
dangerous pathogens are destroyed by the
beneficial bacteria that's growing
during the fermentation which is pretty
cool I mean they're just microorganisms
they don't have to do that but they do
and at this point we are ready to finish
our sriracha so we're going to go ahead
and transfer that into a blender we're
going to add some white distilled
vinegar and then we're going to blend
that smooth again and please be careful
if you're using a smaller blender this
is not exactly the kind of stuff you
want flying out into your face and once
we've processed our fermented pepper and
vinegar into a very very very smooth
puree we're going to go ahead and dump
that through a fine strainer into a
saucepan and we're going to take a
spatula we're going to push everything
or at least as much as we can get
through that strainer so that's going to
take a few minutes but most of it will
go through and all you really should be
left with are all those seed remnants
and bits of skin all right so once
you're sure there is no more liquid
coming out through the strainer we'll go
ahead and discard that and we'll
transfer our saucepan to the stove we'll
place that over medium-high heat and
we'll bring it up to a boil and
basically we're going to boil that for
about five to ten minutes until it's the
thickness that we want and please be
careful because there is sugar in this
you don't want to scorch the bottom so
keep a close eye on it give it a stir
often and because I am genetically
disposed to skimming foam I can't resist
so usually skim a little bit of the foam
off although I have a feeling I'm just
wasting hot sauce okay so if you're some
kind of hot sauce making guru let me
know am I wasting my time skimming I
have a feeling I am
but regardless in the spirit of full
disclosure I did skim and like I said
going to boil that until it reduces
slightly and gets the consistency you're
looking for which I think should be
right about there so while that might
look a little bit on the thin side when
this cools it's going to be perfect as
you'll see so at that point we're going
to turn off the heat let that cool
completely before we try to bottle it
but once it is cooled go ahead and use a
funnel and transfer that into any kind
of serving vessel you want all right
squeeze bottle works great one of these
glass bottles is perfect unfortunately I
lost the cork top that came with this
but luckily I have this wine stopper
that I could use so I put that on there
and it's funny that dude looks kind of
familiar but it just can't place it
God that's gonna drive me crazy actually
know what that's kind of giving me the
creeps
let me switch to a plain cork that's
much better anyway there you go homemade
shots of sauce and sure it took three
days but so what there's like hardly any
work involved come on and then what is
it good served on literally everything
including of course a couple simple
fried eggs as I spewed that on there you
can really see it pretty much has the
exact color and texture of the
store-bought rooster sauce really I
think the taste is almost identical in
fact a fun experiment would be to serve
this to your friend it doesn't know it's
homemade to see if they noticed a
difference and I'm betting they won't so
this time of year you should see lots of
hot red pepper at the farmers market or
just a regular grocery store so why not
buy some and give this beautiful sauce a
try alright so head over to food wishes
calm for all the ingredient amounts and
more info as usual and as always enjoy
you
